[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in complex sentences (e.g., "left them a people without a country").
[LEXICON]: Minor word-choice oddities (e.g., "recovering from its exhaustion").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift to 18th-century village description without clear transition.
[TRANSITION]: Weak links between historical trends (e.g., aristocracy vs. French Revolution impact).

[SYNTAX]: A few long, dense sentences (e.g., "We had given a lead in free trade...") require careful parsing.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures with multiple embedded clauses (e.g., "The whole poem is an allegory...").
[PHRASING]: Occasional abrupt line breaks between poetic quotes and prose.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between literary analysis, historical context, and philosophical critiques (e.g., jumping from Modred’s story to Tennyson’s allegorical intent).
[STRUCTURE]: Subtopics (e.g., Victorian longevity, religious trends, political disillusionment) feel loosely connected despite shared focus on Tennyson.
[CLARITY]: Assumed knowledge of references (e.g., "Malleor," "the second Locksley Hall") without brief contextualization.
